Entries.default:
"Great and terrible things are at work, [Player Name]. And once again, you seem to be in the middle of it."

Aloth is twisting the edge of his sash between his hands, a purposeful frown on his face.
"I promised to tell you what I was doing among the animancers at Port Maje."
"As you may have guessed, I was observing them. Gathering information on the various animancy operation in the region."
"So?"
"I wish I had your clarity."
He sighs through his nose, his lips pressed together.
"What for?"
"I thought you were looking for a particular Leaden Key group."
"Animancy is a subject of particular interest to the Leaden Key. Through it, I hoped to pick up their trail." A spark of pleasure gleams in his eye.
"Yes, and how better to draw them out?"
"And then?"
"That's smart."
"Seems like a pretty vague plan."
"After that incident in Old Vailia, I thought more about the Leaden Key and its particular composition."
"Go on."
"Mostly lunatics in robes, as I recall."

"It's existed for over two thousand years. Say what you will about its motives and methods, but that's an impressive tenure."

He clasps his hands behind his back and begins pacing.
"Oh, very funny." He gives you a sidelong glance, but the corners of his mouth turn up despite it.
"That's when I realized how short-sighted I'd been. To think I could change the Leaden Key without understanding how it works."
"That's when I realized how short-sighted I'd been. To think I could undo the Leaden Key without understanding how it works."

Iselmyr cackles gleefully as Aloth's thoughtful expression dissolves.

After a moment, she fades away once more.
"If you two are finished..." He gives you a sidelong glance, but the corners of his mouth turn up despite it.
"I found references to an ancient Leaden Key cabal in the Deadfire. Possibly one of the oldest, if accounts are credible."
"And they appear to have been working independently - without direct intervention from Thaos - for almost two millennia." He watches you eagerly, waiting for that to sink in.
"You think that by observing them, you can learn how the Leaden Key works."
"And how to reform it. Yes."
"And how to destroy it. Yes."
"Very well. How do we find them?"
"So they're old. What does it matter?"
"Most sources refer to them as the 'Painted Masks.' But I haven't met anyone here who knows that name."
"There's the challenge." He stops pacing.
"I don't know where in the Deadfire they are, exactly. But I was hoping we could look for them together." He folds his hands, looking hopeful and a little sheepish.
"I'll help as best I can."
"Don't worry, Aloth. I promise we'll find them, one way or another."
"I believe you." He smiles, but worry crinkles the corners of his eyes.
"I don't want to promise the impossible. There's not much to go on, but we'll try."
"That's all I ask, [Player Name]." He bows his head.
"I understand. I only hope that if we run across them, you'll allow me to investigate." He bows his head.
"Find an ancient Leaden Key sect somewhere in a monster-ridden archipelago. Sure, easy."
He chuckles. "For the Watcher who survived the wrath of the gods, I would hope so."
"That's where it gets complicated." He purses his lips.
"Merely a first step." Still, his ears redden.
"Don't you see? If I understood how they've continued to operate, I could learn how to reform the Leaden Key."
"Don't you see? If I understood how they've persisted, I could learn how to destroy the Leaden Key."
As you near a post with a curious symbol painted onto it, Aloth lays a hand on your arm to stop you.
"Very well."
"Couldn't we do this later?"
"Don't worry, I already know you're working for the Leaden Key."
"Don't tell me you're working for another secret organization..."
"I don't have time for this."
"This is about the reason I came to Deadfire. The people I've been searching for." He looks meaningfully from you back to the Engwithan tower.
"I'm afraid not." He looks meaningfully from you back to the painted post and the Engwithan tower.
"I now know better than to keep secrets from a man who can read souls." He smiles, but it's strained.
Entries.female: "I now know better than to keep secrets from a woman who can read souls." He smiles, but it's strained.

Entries.default: "I wouldn't insist if it weren't important."
"Oh, very funny." He smiles, but it's strained.
"I've made some missteps over the last few years. As a result, I've thought more about the Leaden Key's composition."
"The Wahaki of Ori o Koīki paint their faces."
"Actually, I may know who they are. Long ago, Thaos visited a Wahaki chieftain."
"I don't understand. What did you find?" Trepidation creeps into his expression.
"Truly? Then perhaps we'll find something there." Hope sparks in his blue eyes as he looks to you.
Then, his gaze turns back to the ruined Engwithan tower. And the canoes beside it.
"Please, let's look around."
"What exactly have we set in motion, Watcher?"
"The Rauataians we passed will doubtless spread word of what you've done in Hasongo."

"But others will want to know what you've seen, [Player Name].

"They'll look to you for answers." He watches you uncertainly, his brow furrowed.
"I have to report truthfully."
"I'll tell them what they need to hear."
"I'm worried about what that will lead to."
"What I say makes no difference."
"Don't you worry what will come next? What events you might move forward?"
"What is this really about, Aloth?"
"If I thought about it that much, I'd never do anything."
"What someone else does with my words is on them, not me."
"Of course. That's why I choose my words carefully."
"I doubt my response will mean anything irrevocable."
"This is no small matter." He pinches the bridge of his nose.
"You make it sound so simple." He spreads his hands in exasperation.
"As am I." His frown deepens.
"You heard Eothas himself reveal his plan to end the cycle of reincarnation." He speaks through gritted teeth, looking around as if afraid someone will overhear.
"Now, the rest of the Deadfire will want to know what happened in Magran's Teeth."
"I don't have any."
"I know. That worries me."
"I can sympathize." He gives you a sad half-smile.
"Well. At least I'm not alone in this." He smiles ruefully.

"It reminds me of the question that drew me to the Deadfire.

"The one I've been avoiding." He rubs the back of his neck.
"So you were spying on your friends."
He winces. "Not out of malice. There was simply no better way."
[Listen.]
"How the Leaden Key works? How would you learn about that?"
"By studying its origins, of course." He pauses long enough to show you a triumphant flash of teeth.
"Fye, dinnae spur the lad."
"We've got more pressing matters. I can't make a detour for this."
"We'll go."
"If there's time."
"That's all I ask, [Player Name]." He bows his head.
"Thank you, [Player Name]." He smiles warmly, but there's a hint of trepidation in his expression.
"I don't know how you can be so certain."
"I still don't understand how you can truly know what they will mean."
"This is a prudent time for me to explain something." He licks his lips, considering his next words.

"Whoever lives here, they've obviously been here a very long time."

He looks at the post with its strangely-painted symbol.
"Anyway, it's late. I suppose that's enough from me."
"Anyway, there's daylight yet. I suppose that's enough from me."
"These are Wahaki lands, I say. That symbol is a warning to outsiders."
"Hope you got a while. 'Cause I got lots to say about their motives and methods."
"And that looks strangely like the Leaden Key insignia. But... twisted somehow." He cocks his head as if to examine it from another angle.

"I'm sure. But imagine what we could learn from them." 

He turns back to you.

"Relax, Edér. I'm not defending them."

He turns back to you.
